content.user_title: Create Agile Release Plans with Sprint Templates
content.value_statement: Teams struggle to organize complex projects into structured sprint plans. This skill generates comprehensive release plans with sprint schedules, task tracking codes, and timeline roadmaps following agile best practices.
actual_capabilities: Generate structured release plans with sprint-by-sprint breakdown
Create unique sprint codes (SPRINT-001, SPRINT-002) and task codes (T-001, T-002) for tracking
Build timeline roadmaps grouped by quarter, month, or project phase
Define sprint goals, durations, tasks, and dependencies with clear formatting
Provide templates for short (1-3 sprints) and long (6+ sprints) releases
limitations: Does not integrate with project management tools or APIs
Does not track actual sprint progress or update tickets
Does not generate burndown charts or velocity reports
Only provides planning templates and documentation

use_cases.title: Plan a New Product Release
use_cases.description: Generate a complete release plan for a new product feature or version, including sprint breakdown, task assignments, timeline, and milestones.
use_cases.target_user: Product managers and team leads organizing new releases

use_cases.title: Create Quarterly Roadmaps
use_cases.description: Structure multiple sprints into quarterly planning cycles with clear phases, dependencies, and key milestone dates.

use_cases.title: Communicate Timelines to Stakeholders
use_cases.description: Generate stakeholder-friendly roadmap documents showing key milestones, sprint themes, and delivery dates.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Sprint Plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Create an agile release plan for a [project type] called [name] with [number] sprints over [timeframe] for a team of [size] developers. Include sprint themes, goals, tasks with ticket codes, and dependencies.
prompt_templates.scenario: Getting started with a new project release

prompt_templates.title: Feature Release with Milestones
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a [n]-sprint release plan for [feature name]. Include alpha, beta, and production launch milestones. Use SPRINT-00X format for sprints and T-00X format for tasks. Show how sprints depend on each other.
prompt_templates.scenario: Planning a feature release with specific milestones

prompt_templates.title: Quarterly Roadmap
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a quarterly roadmap for [quarter/year] covering [n] sprints. Group sprints by month or phase. Include key milestones like feature freeze, beta launch, and production release dates.

prompt_templates.title: MVP Launch Plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Plan an MVP launch in [n] sprints. Front-load critical infrastructure work, include testing and polish sprints, and define clear success criteria for each sprint. Use the MVP pattern with foundation, features, and launch phases.

output_examples.input: Create a 4-sprint release plan for a fitness tracking app with 2 developers over 8 weeks
output: # Release Plan: Fitness Tracker App v1.0
**Release Goal**: Launch MVP with core tracking features
- SPRINT-004: MVP launched to app stores

output_examples.input: Generate a 6-sprint release plan for an e-commerce checkout system with 3 developers
output: **Release Goal**: Launch new checkout system with multiple payment options
**Goal**: Setup payment infrastructure and API integrations

best_practices: Front-load risky or complex work in early sprints to leave buffer time for unexpected issues
Use descriptive sprint themes (e.g., Payment Integration) rather than generic names (Sprint 1)
Keep task codes sequential across the entire release (T-001 through T-050) for consistent tracking
anti_patterns: Creating vague tasks like T-001: Work on backend instead of specific items like T-001: Stripe API integration
Planning 100% capacity without accounting for meetings, bugs, and unexpected work (aim for 80%)
Reusing task codes or using inconsistent formatting (use T-001, never T-1)

faq.question: What sprint duration should I use?
faq.answer: Two-week sprints are most common and provide good balance between planning and delivery. One-week sprints work for small teams needing fast feedback. Three-week sprints suit complex features requiring longer development cycles.

faq.question: How many tasks should be in each sprint?
faq.answer: Plan for 3-5 tasks per sprint. This keeps work focused and manageable. Each task should be completable within the sprint by one developer. Factor in 80% capacity for realistic planning.

faq.question: How do I handle sprint dependencies?
faq.answer: Document dependencies explicitly in each sprint. Schedule dependent sprints sequentially. When possible, design work to run in parallel. Always include buffer time for blocked work.

faq.question: Should I include a buffer sprint?
faq.answer: Yes, include a testing or polish sprint before launch. This provides space for bug fixes, performance optimization, and unexpected issues without delaying the release date.

faq.question: How do I organize a long release (6+ sprints)?
faq.answer: Group sprints into phases: Foundation (1-2 sprints), Features (3-4 sprints), Integration/Testing (1 sprint), Launch (1 sprint). This creates natural checkpoints and makes the plan easier to communicate.

faq.question: What makes a good sprint goal?
faq.answer: A good sprint goal is one clear sentence describing what the sprint accomplishes. It should be measurable and meaningful to stakeholders. Examples: Setup payment infrastructure, Build responsive checkout flow.
